title: Will the iPhone 12 be the best iPhone? - Quora

response.answer_text: In this day and age where new technologies are often leaked to oblivion months before their release, it’s very difficult to be genuinely impressed when they eventually come out. Many new features of the iPhone 12 lineup were already anticipated two, three, even four months ago. We knew about 5G. We knew about MagSafe for wireless charging. We knew about LiDAR. We knew about the “new” flat-edged design. We knew about iPhone 12 Mini. We knew about A14 Bionic. We knew that Apple was removing the charger and earpods from the box. But all the leaks also came with another drawback— they made us anticipate for features that never happened. Almost all of the mainstream tech media were teasing supposed “actual renders” for the iPhone 12, which appeared to have a smaller notch, four rear cameras, and even USB Type-C— none of which actually happened. A 120 Hz refresh rate display was highly anticipated since the beginning of 2020. That didn’t happen either (I’ll get into this later).  That’s not to say that the iPhone 12 lineup didn’t impress. Let’s start with the “HOORAY!”: iPhone 12 finally has OLED.OLED has also made it possible for Apple to shrink the bezels around the display, which is a significant improvement over iPhone 11’s ugly thick bezels.iPhone 12 Pro’s ProRAW image format is genuinely impressive. At last, the “Pro” naming scheme is no longer just marketing jargon— it now actually means something.Similarly, live Dolby Vision video recording is also really impressive. Now, I don’t think this is quite going to “revolutionize the film industry” like Apple claims it will, but nonetheless it will certainly make amateur videos much higher quality. Then there’s the “MEH…”: MagSafe is a bit of a mixed bag. Personally, I have never had any issues aligning phones to wireless chargers, and I’m not convinced that it’s a real problem for other people as well. Furthermore, the name really bothers me, because “MagSafe” was originally the name of a very useful MacBook feature that prevented users from tripping over the charging cable, thus causing the MacBook to be dragged off the table. So why is this new wireless charging feature called MagSafe? Doesn’t make sense to me.What is good about MagSafe is that is allows accessories to magnetically attach to the back of the phone. That wallet attachment is particularly nice.Right now, 5G is a gimmick for 99% of the population. I have a 5G phone and I live in a city with 5G towers everywhere, and believe me, it’s not all it’s cracked up to be. So far, I have never been in a situation where I’ve been thankful to have 5G. No doubt that 5G is the future, but the way I see it, we are at least a few years away from seeing any practical mainstream use for 5G— and in a few years, you’ll be upgrading your iPhone anyway, so…On one hand, I love the look of the “new” flat-edged iPhone. On the other hand, I can’t help but feel like the sharper edges will make the phone less comfortable to hold for long periods of time. Then again, some people might argue that it’s a good idea to discourage people from being on their phones all the time.Ceramic Shield is supposedly “tougher than any smartphone glass”, but let’s not forget, this isn’t the first time Apple has made such a claim. Apple has previously made similar claims about their Sapphire Glass on the Apple Watch, but scientific tests have proven it to be no more resistant to scratching and cracking than regular glass. So until independent durability tests come out, I am skeptical of the Ceramic Shield. Lastly, there’s the “FUCKING HELL!”: There’s really only one genuinely bad thing about the iPhone 12 lineup— 60 Hz refresh rate displays, all across the board. Even without the constant tech media pressure to upgrade to 120 Hz displays, the fact that even mid-range Android phones have higher refresh rate displays should’ve been a sign to Apple that this is a must-have feature. Because, when you walk into a Best Buy or a Verizon store or a Target, and you see the iPhone 12 Pro demo right next to the Samsung Galaxy S20 demo (120 Hz) and the Google Pixel 5 demo (90 Hz), the FIRST thing that consumers will notice is that the S20 and Pixel 5 displays look so much smoother. Even the difference between 60 Hz and 90 Hz is palpable. And the excuse of “they had to choose between 5G and 120 Hz to preserve battery life” doesn’t cut it, either. The Samsung Galaxy S20 manages both, and still has decent battery life. We gave Apple the pass for not having high refresh rate displays in 2019 because very few companies were doing it, and nobody was sure whether it was a must-have feature for average consumers. But now in late 2020, it’s no longer justifiable to price phones at $1000 that don’t also have high refresh rate displays.

Maybe I would give it a miss…except…it comes in blue and I love blue, and it is styled very much like the old iPhone 4 which I really liked the design of. …so maybe? Yeah, if I had a hunk of spare change I would rather get that then a set of 8 garden boxes or a new rug and a half for the dining room or the other sort of stuff I have been spending that kind of money on lately. Other people can have very different valid situations and choices. Including “I have an iPhone 11 and that seems good enough”, and “I have an iPhone 6 and don’t care what is new”, and “I have a hand me down iPhone 8, and would love the 12, but would rather be able to pay rent and you know buy food”, oh and also “I like android phones better”, and even “I don’t like cellphones and don’t want one in my life”, and well as “can I eat it‽ does it smell like a butt‽ (presumably this is the option of a dog) However all the stuff that goes into that choice is personal. If anything is improved on any product that is reason for someone to buy it, but likewise if near everything is improved on a product there is someone out there that it will be utterly wrong for.
